Damir G. Martin:

âThis is my depiction of how could Carnotuaurus look like if it had feather filament. The smaller one, with the crest is a male, the bigger, dull carno in the background is a female. Male is trying to impress the female just like the modern birds are with all kinds of noises, dance moves and messed up hairstyles.â Read the rest of his comment here

This is very pretty, and Iâd be the last to insult its merit from an artistic perspective. The feather texture is very well-done, and the colors are gorgeous. I also acknowledge that the artist states this is meant to be purely speculative, and is not meant to represent scientific gospel.

However, Iâm going to have to play devilâs advocate here. Incidentally, Carnotaurus was the first theropod for whom a comprehensive skin impression - showing a covering of definite scales from many parts of the body, and no sign of feathers - was known. From a purely scientific perspective, how is it any better to reconstruct a definitely-scaly animal as being covered in feathers in the name of being âspeculativeâ than it is to reconstruct a definitely-feathered dromaeosaur as scaly for the same reason? Is this not something of a paleo double standard?

Is the feather-craze taking over the realm of paleoart to the point of clouding our judgement?

(Unrelatedly, it is incredibly unlikely that such primitive feathers could be blue, since the structure necessary for blue coloration is only possible in more advanced feathers.)

-

Czerkas, Stephen A.; Czerkas, Sylvia J. (1997). âThe Integument and Life Restoration of Carnotaurusâ. In Wolberg, D. I.; Stump, E.; Rosenberg, G. D.. Dinofest International. Academy of Natural Sciences, Philadelphia. pp. 155â158.
